isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 2000, 4000, 8000 - CHASSIS ACCESSORIES - TROUBLESHOOTING - Frame Mounted 7-Way Trailer Socket With Tractor, or Truck With Trailer Connections

svcproc.title: Frame Mounted 7-Way Trailer Socket With Tractor, or Truck With Trailer Connections

table.title: Frame Mounted 7-Way Trailer Socket With Tractor, or Truck With Trailer Connections

entry.para: Does the marker light circuit to the trailer function properly?
Do the tractor marker/ tail lights function properly?
See LIGHT SYSTEMS section for tractor tail light trouble- shooting.
Disconnect conn. (183) and with headlight switch in the park or headlight position, measure voltage from circuit 58E to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 58E, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (183) and disconnect conn. (13). At (13) with headlight switch in the park or headlight position, measure voltage from circuit 58E to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 58E, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (13). At conn. (149) with headlight switch in park or headlight position, measure voltage from circuit MARKER to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit MARKER, then repair.
Does the stop light circuit to the trailer function properly?
Do the tractor stop lights function properly?
See LIGHT SYSTEMS section for tractor stop light trouble- shooting.
Remove fuse F29 and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install F29. At fuse and circuit 14J, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14J/14S, then repair.
Remove relay (R4), and at the socket and circuit 70C, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 70C, then repair.
At relay socket (R4), measure voltage from circuit 70C to 70-G.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 70 G or 11-G to cab ground, then repair.
While an assistant applies the service brakes, at relay socket (R4) circuit 70D, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 70D, then repair.
Bench test relay (R4) by measuring the resistance from term. 30 to 87A.
Bench test relay (R4) by applying +12V to term. 86 and ground to 85. Then measure resistance from term. 30 to 87.
Re-install relay (R4) and disconnect conn. (183). At (183) while an assistant applies service brakes, measure voltage to ground at circuit 70H.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 70F or 70H, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (183) and disconnect conn. (13). At (13) and circuit 70H, measure voltage to ground while an assistant applies service brakes.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 70H, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (13). At conn. (149) and circuit STOP, measure voltage to ground while an assistant applies service brakes.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit STOP, then repair.
Does the backup light circuit to the trailer function properly?
Do the tractor backup lights function properly?
See LIGHT SYSTEMS section for tractor backup light trouble- shooting.
Disconnect conn. (182). With key switch in ignition position and transmission in reverse, measure voltage from circuit 71B to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage at conn. (182) which is the splice point for circuits 71A and 71B, then repair.
Disconnect conn. (13) and reconnect conn. (182). At (13) with key switch in ignition position and transmission in reverse, measure voltage from circuit 71C to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 71C, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (13). At (149) with key switch in ignition position and transmission in reverse, measure voltage from circuit AUX to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit AUX, then repair.
Does the tail light circuit to the trailer function properly?
Do the tractor marker/ tail lights function properly?
See LIGHT SYSTEMS section for tractor tail light trouble- shooting.
Disconnect conn. (182) and with the headlight sw. in the park or headlight position, measure voltage from cir. 68C to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 68C, then repair.
Disconnect conn. (13) and reconnect conn. (182). At (13) with headlight sw. in the park or headlight position, measure voltage from circuit 68D to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 68D, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (13). With headlight sw. in the park or headlight position, measure voltage at (149) from circuit TAIL to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit TAIL, then repair.
Do tractor turn signals function properly?
See CAB ACCES- SORIES section for tractor turn signal trouble- shooting.
Does the right turn signal circuit to the trailer function properly?
Remove fuse F28 and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install fuse F28 and at fuse and circuit 14H, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14H/14S, then repair.
Remove relay (R6), and at the socket and circuit 57K, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 57K, then repair.
At relay socket (R6), measure voltage from circuit 57K to 57-GA.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 57-GA/ 11-GF, then repair.
Move turn signal switch to right turn position and at relay socket (R6) circuit 57F, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 57F, then repair.
Bench test relay (R6) by measuring the resistance from terminal 30 to 87A.
Bench test relay (R6) by applying +12V to term. 86 and gnd. to 85. Then measure resistance from term. 30 to 87.
Re-install relay (R6), and disconnect conn. (182). At (182) and circuit 57E, measure voltage to ground with right turn signals switched on.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 57E, then repair.
Disconnect (13) and reconnect (182). With right turn signals switch on, measure voltage from circuit 57E to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 57E, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (13). At conn. (149) with right turn signals switched on, measure voltage from circuit RT TURN to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit RT TURN, then repair.
Does the left turn signal circuit to the trailer function properly?
Remove fuse F27 and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install fuse F27 and at fuse and circuit 14G, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14G/14S, then repair.
Remove relay (R5), and at the socket and circuit 56K, measure voltage to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 56K, then repair.
At relay socket (R5), measure voltage from circuit 56K to 56-GA.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 56-GA/ 11-GF, then repair.
Move turn signal switch to the left turn position and at relay socket (R5) circuit 56F, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 56F, then repair.
Bench test relay (R5) by measuring the resistance from term. 30 to 87A.
Bench test relay (R5) by applying +12V to term. 86 and gnd. to 85. Then measure resistance from term. 30 to 87.
Re-install relay (R5) and at conn. (182) and cir. 56E, measure voltage to ground with left turn signals switched on.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 56E, then repair.
Disconnect conn. (13) and reconnect (182). With left turn signal switched on, measure voltage from circuit 56E to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 56E, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (13) and at conn. (149), with left turn signals switched on, measure voltage from circuit LT TURN to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit LT TURN, then repair.
At connector (149) and circuit GROUND, measure resistance to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit GROUND, 11-GD/ 11-GF, then repair.
